title: Quick release Extruder - X carriage - E3D V6

description.text:
Based on my X carriage http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:154258 I have redesigned the X carriage and extruder to suit E3D V6.
For a while i have been limited in X axis travel by a combination of X carriage & extruder ( stepper motor) so i have designed this to be as compact as possible. I also wanted to make it so that the extruder/ E3D could be removed easily with a quick release so i can swap between extruders 39/11 geared 3mm & 1.75 mm direct drive.
(Scroll to bottom for updates)
This is the 3 mm version ( M8 hobbed bolt on 39:11 gear ratio) i plan to adapt/redesign the extruder to a 1.75 mm filament direct drive in the coming weeks ( once this has proven to be OK ...work in progress)
Thanks to bettak at Grabcad for the hotend
https://grabcad.com/library/e3d-all-metal-hotend-v6-1
&
Anthony Tripper for the herringbone gears
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:400456/#files If all works as planned ill do a hardware list / exploded view If you like this thing ...hit the button Updates:-
Feb 6th . Added notch in extruder body to help with cable routing.

Extruder body V2 R2.2.stl ( see jpeg image)
Left original V2 R2.stl if you dont need / want this

Feb 12th> added direct drive extruder for 1.75 filament . Based on Mk8 hobbed drive bush March 6th > minor changes to the extruder body to make for easier post print clean up. Now version V2 R2.5

This is the same model and file as the first Mk.III design, the only difference is that I used the alternate gun mount (included in the print), thus the A2. The overall design is simple and geometric with no raised detail to allow for easier filling and sanding of the flat surfaces. The Gatling gun and optics are kit parts, as this vehicle is designed to be detailed with model kit parts. Think of the A.M.V.P. as a platform for whatever you want to put on it, the more stuff you pile on the vehicle the better. I have found that anime and armor kits offer a plethora of weapons and detail pieces. The extra gun mount is designed to be used with a gun from a kit or whatever you want to use as armament. I used a raft and a support grid when printing, that being said, it is really necessary for the hull, but difficult to remove from around the wheels.
If you require the model split it to sections, it is available in the (separate files) version. All the parts on the model fit really tight, so some filing and sanding will be needed to get everything to fit and move well. Hope you enjoy this little model as much as I have.
I used a raft and supports in printing this file. Supports are necessary for the hull, difficult to remove from around the wheels.

comments.text: you could also make the axles part of the wheels, so you don't need a grid/raft, and make them snap into the under carriage.
comments.author: poodull

comments.text: I had thought of making wheels and axles one piece, however I didn't want to lose the detail on the hubs.  Thanks for the feedback it will be useful in designing the MK.IV.
comments.author: poodull

comments.text: looks like you need supports for the main body and a grid/raft for the axles.  Since it would be a waste to grid out the whole thing, it would be nice to have them split into 3 files... no supports/grid, supports, grid.
comments.author: poodull

comments.text: How bad did the prints fail? The first Mk.III I printed failed spectacularly because of an extruder problem, but I was still able to assemble it as seen in the pics. You can split the in half using slicer software, I used supports, but the problem was removing the support especially around the wheels. I will split the file hopefully it will work better. the point of the Mk.III was to have it all in one file, that being said, the hull needs support, however the wheels do not.
comments.author: poodull

description.text:
This is a derivative of the Plastruder MK3 design I've been working on. The goal is to make the plastruder into a printable design that can be made on a MakerBot. I also wanted to take on an ambitious project to put the new AOI plugin, MetaCAD through its paces. Learn about metacad at http://www.metacad.org This extruder design uses 5 printed pieces: two halves that bolt together for the housing, 2 dinos to put it at the right height for printing, and a simple insulator retainer to keep the PTFE in the right spot. The rest of the design is mostly the motor, heater barrel assembly, electronics, and a 625 bearing to provide the pinching force. It has yet to be tested, but ideally it will be simpler to put together, as well as a sturdier design with no squeaks! I've printed all the parts on my travel bot, and as soon as I get home, I'll be assembling them and testing them out. A few design notes:
  • no more layered construction! that was a hack to make it laser-cuttable. new design is two halves bolted together. one half holds the motor + filament, the other half holds the idler wheel.
  • idler wheel switched from acrylic + 608 bearing to a single 625 bearing. smaller, more compact, and nothing but a nearly indestructible bearing to break. should be quite a bit more consistant
  • 4 adjustable screws with captive nuts for setting the pinch wheel tension. you'll be able to adjust it on the fly, without any sort of dis-assembly. hopefully the abs will act as a sort of spring as well
    • a few things i'd like to change yet:
  • rotate the captive nut slot on the right-housing to be in-line with print direction for a better finish.
  • switch the captive nut / bolt head holes between right and left housings to improve print quality for both (adjust on right side instead of left side)

Haven't tried it yet, but the process will be something like this:
  • bolt motor to left housing
  • bolt washer + 625 bearing + washer to right housing
  • insert captive nuts in appropriate places
  • insert filament
  • bolt left and right housings together, and clamp down on filament a bit
  • bolt on heater barrel assembly using captive nuts
  • bolt left and right dinos on... m3 bolts directly into plastic (hope it works!)

Needed some rubber feet for the Flashforge Dreamer printer. Print this (x4) in SemiFlex (preferred) or NinjaFlex.

Print with about 4 shells and 25% infill. SemiFlex or Zentoolworks Flex seems to work better than NinjaFlex. You may have to scale down to 90-94% if it is a tad too long (originally tried with ninjaflex which squeezes in a little easier). I may upload a second version with a better fit later after I get a chance to look into it.  
90 is perfect for me. 0.25 layer, 4 shells, 25% infill, 230c, 50c printed at 30mm/s

Goals of the Project
  • Create an articulating arm that can be used to hold phones, cameras or whatever you can imagine.
  • Try to gear everything around 1/4-20 Nut and Bolts. They're very cheap, easy to get and come in various sizes. Any other hardware should be available at homedepot.
  • Creating interconnecting parts/joints that only needed to be printed once and using the various bolt lengths as a way to resize or adjust the size of the part.
  • Open source the whole project. With the source models as examples, people can easily create new parts or improve existing ones.
    • Link To Parts
    NEWEST PARTS
  • Arduino Testing Rig : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:810811
    • NEWER PARTS
  • Rotate Base Clamp: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:704649
  • Universal Joint : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:704652
  • Tilt Mount Joint : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:704656
  • Arm Joints : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:705805
    • NEW PARTS
  • Mini Claw Grip: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:680222
  • Spring Phone Grip v2 : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:680315
    • ORIGINAL SET
  • Elbow Joint : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:668136
  • Double Ball Joint : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:668158
  • Three Axis Cube : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:668118
  • Resizable Claw Grip : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:668215
  • Spring Phone Grip : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:668183
  • Clamp : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:668194
  • Rotate / Angle Joint : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:668228

Possible Future Parts
Spring Clamp : I need a really good large torsion spring. Haven't found one to suit the design I had in mind. Any helping finding one would be greatly appreciated.

About the Project
I always loved camera arms and find them useful to do various things. But they tend to be pretty pricey that I just wait on ebay to find cheap parts from china. When I got my first 3D Printer recently I hoped that there was something I could 3D print but found nothing but some random parts from various people that I can probably make an arm with. I wanted a one stop specially design system that allows me to create whatever size arm I needed at any specific moment but using very very cheap parts I can easily get at homedepot. So the birth of qInch... which is really play on Quarter Inch Nuts and Bolts that are the core of the system. So here it is. I will introduce new parts as time goes on, I'm also open to new ideas, like if you have a really cool part Idea I'll gladly help you model it and included it into the project.

comments.text: there is several reasons why I went with quarter inch nuts+bolts then metric. First of all is cost, anything metric costs 5x more here in the states. Local availability is another problem, hard to get good metric stuff at a local homedepot / lowes. Another reason is that quarter inch threaded screw is almost universal, all camera equipment use that size for tripods, connections, etc. Since its a pretty widely used size, I can get threaded rods, nuts, couplers, inserts, washers, etc in that size. Another big thing is that is comes with a hex head which for alot of things I made helps a lot, where metric the more common head is a round hex cap, which isn't as useful as a hex head in some cases.
comments.author: krokus57

remixed_from.author: richard_j_m
remixed_from.title: Cable chain link to X end for i3

description.text: A remixed version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10946 to be easier to print. I had problems with the slight overhang in the front of the link bending upwards when printing the cable chain so I added a 1mm support under the front to keep it level. Prints like a charm now and the support is easy to remove with a knife or a file. I've also added the two custom mounts that I've designed for the X-carrige of my Prusa i3. The extruder side simply clips on to the NEMA stepper motor for the extruder.

Just print and trim down the support either with a knife, file or sandpaper.  
I would recommend you to print the mounts in the orientation they are placed with support set to "touching the buildplate" or similar for the best looking result and strongest parts.  
The "X-motor" mount might need a drop of glue to stay in place depending on the precision of the print, I did not need it though.

author: jesuscastilloalbalate

description.text: A tall skinny hour glass

Remix of josephrueter's great sticky tape dispenser, with the requested hanging hole in handle. Also fixed the manifold... I'm still thinking of making a sharp slope to the curring end, but printed it out with the hole to test how it works.  
I expect the actual tape-holder part may have trouble letting the tape roll freely because it's only supported at two places, one place against the pulling... fixing that would detract from the current flat elegance, though.

Printed it in ABS, the tape-reel holder has fairly large tabs at the ends to hold the reel, so I think PLA might break. Needs some cooling after first layers of course, as the top is so close to the hot-bed it may be hard to print without melting.  
Might try solid, but I printed this with 20% fill on Buildtak platform and it's quite solid. The bottom edge against the Buildtak mat makes for nice sharp cutting edge, although I'm thinking of also printing it with an edge next time.  
Other ideas on my planning board are smoothing out the curve on the backside, which is pretty angular right now, and making the back-end of the handle larger to accommodate a larger hole for hanging off hooks etc. No idea if I'll get around to that, though...

remixed_from.title: Lasercut tiles for Settlers of Catan

title: Lasercut tiles for Settlers of Catan

description.text:
Our laser cutter doesn't accept svgs, we've got to go through dxfs, and the original didn't export so well in inkscape. 
So I decided to vectorise it. This is the result. A little less busy, and a few things need fixing, double cuts and the like. I'll clean it up at some point.
Cut one layer and do the other one fairly low power to avoid scorching. I haven't cut it myself, but someone else has cut it successfully.

description.text: Rollingball parts 2nd

title: The qInch Project - Three Axis Cube

description.text:
Main Project Link : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:668017 This is a pretty simple idea, a cube that you can run 3 bolts threw. There is an A and B side, both sides together can be used to build structures by using 1/4-20 nuts and bolts. Or you can use the cube with other qInch parts to make whatever you need. I actually went and tried to build a side table using threaded rods, bolts, nuts and couplers. Its not steady at all, its flexes a lot but It still works for my needs. Down the lines I'll print more cubes and get more rods to add more support between the 4 legs to hopefully make the table flex less. All in all, it proved to be a pretty good proof of concept. If anyone knows where I can get machined metal parts done cheaply, send me a msg. I would love this part in metal to give it more strength when trying to build things with. Future Plans
At some point I might make a variation of this but with all the holes are at 45 degree angle. Don't really have any ideas for an application for such a part though. Side note, its funny when my cats jump on the table and try to balance themselves on it as it wobbles. Its like a kid ride for them. Freecad source included

  • 1/4 x 1 1/2 inch Neoprene Washer
  • One 1 1/2 Inch 1/4-20 bolt and 3 nuts.
  • Whatever length bolt needed or threaded rod with nut or lock nuts.
This base is meant to be used with a Lego mini-fig to match the scale of 1 inch wide base miniatures.

The scad file has a number of useful variables including knobdiam and crossbars.  I've included stl files with crossbars set to either 0 or 2.  4.85 mm knobdiam is working well in the prints I've got, but if your printer is different, having this variable might help.

Of course, if your printer is generous or stingy with the filament, that would need to be changed. I also posted it on Cuusoo hoping that LEGO would produce something like this in-house. title: The qInch Project : Spring Phone Grip

description.text:
Main Project Page : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:668017 Trying something different, instead of something that you have to tighten down, I decided to try using spring tension to hold a phone while attached to a tripod. In the build there is 3 holes to attach this to a tripod or an arm of you're creation using qInch parts. In one picture I have 3 inch bolts as a rail system that allows the extension part move up and down. This is enough to hold a phone in place while using the highest placement to hold the spring. In the next set I have 6 inch bolts and using the lowest placement which can easily hold a 7 inch tablet. Hardware Used
  • Any length 1/4-20 bolts you need to match the height of the device you want to clamp onto.
  • Three Nuts.
  • Four 1/4-20 bolts that is 1/2 inch length to hold the springs
  • Any spring size or tension strength you want to use to hold you're device.
    • You should be able to find usable springs at homedepot or whatever local hardware store. The springs I used for this project was from a set I ordered from amazon, its has a decent amount of variations for DIY projects. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000K7M36W/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 Freecad Source Included.

title: Customizable Parametric Battery Holder (AAA, AA, C, D)

description.text:
Series battery holder for AAA to D sized batteries.
NOTE:
This is a work in progress and does not work great at the moment. I have recently re-written this and significantly simplified the scad file. I have not yet printed many of the battery sizes; they may not all work! This thing is a based entirely on flummer's battery box for AA Cells: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:331394 I have simplified a few things and parameterized it, but Flummer did all the hard work. This version adds the ability to define different battery sizes and has a few more options.

NOTE: The AAA solution is not quite right; it needs some work.
Check your battery clip size before you print! This may not fit your clips! Select your battery size, number of cells and flange preferences. It is possible to define more battery sizes in the OpenSCAD file. Notable changes from the original:
  • Alternated cells +/-; -/+ to make hookup simpler
  • accommodates cells from AA-D (still working on AAA)
  • removable bolt flanges and custom flange placement
    • Variables

comments.text: Hello, there seems to be an issue with solder lug as you increase the battery diameter. I noticed that with bigger diameter batteries like the 18650, the solder lug doesn't reach out the bottom and the clip sticks too far above. I'm mentioning this in case you revisit this work in progress. Not sure there is a perfect solution but I would suggest adding a cutout on the bottom so the solder lug can be accessable and letting the clip sink in more into the holder.

description.text:
This cone has a centered hole. Use it for printer calibration among other purposes. Printing cones or cylinders may put your printer stability and frequency response to test since you have both axis moving at the same time. With this cone you will check your printer stability and calibration when the upper circles of the cone are made at a higher relative speed. Thanks!
All the best!

title: The qInch Project : Rotate / Angle Joint

description.text: Main Project Page : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:668017 Trying to duplicate how the magic arm's connecting joint works. Using a ball joint added complexity and harder to used. Changed it up a bit and used an elbow type connection instead. So the idea is that you can set the rotation then use the screw cap to tighten in place. Then you can tighten how you want the angle to be. It was a learning experience and figure out how to make parts screw in together but overall I'm not all that happy with how this joint works. I am going to do variation of the double ball joint that would perform the same function that this joint was designed to do but with much less complexity and increased ease of use. Freecad Source Included

comments.text:
Thanks Andychn!
the secret is to try and try again until you get it right :)
That's what Rapid Prototyping is for right?
My first few prototypes did not even fit properly. For designers who want to design male/female threads, model a CAD design of the male and female thread on a small size first and print them out. If it fits, use the design on the actual final design and print it out. Saves time and material. I learnt it the hard way hehe ;)

"It was found lodged against an abutment in Van Nuys."  
Rebadge your Toyota/Scion/Lexus!  Really, this will work for just about any car.  
I decided to rebadge my 2010 Scion Xb. These badges were designed specifically for that purpose, but I think the badges and the process can be used for just about any car.  
On my vehicle the area for the front badge is slightly larger than that of the rear badge, hence to the 2 badge files. The .STL and .SKP files are attached so you can change the badge to anything you want.

I made the files in Sketchup. I got the two colors by stopping the prints when the printer began working on the lettering and switched the filament. You could certainly print in just one color and then paint over the text to make it stand out. You can then use 3M Automotive Mounting Tape to attach the badges to your car.
You will, however, need to remove your original badges. How you do that depends on the type of car you have. A quick internet query should get you on your way.
Additionally, chances are your car surface, like mine, is not completely flat. To overcome this issue and ensure your badge sits as flush as possible on your car, place your printed badge on a baking sheet in the over for 5 minutes at 200 degrees so it becomes malleable. Take it out, it will be hot, and press it onto the surface of the car where you want it to be until the plastic cools and conforms to the slight curved surface of the car. Then you can attach it to your vehicle using the 3M tape.

title: Filament Width Sensor - TSL1402R + Arduino Mega (Work-in-progress)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: WORK IN PROGESS This is my attempt to replicate flipper's filament width sensor but with a TSL1402R sensor, a Mega board and a big display :) Video: http://youtu.be/qB5h6nYoD0Q The case is pretty much inspired by flipper's design, with the exception of the hinge. This is very useful if you want to use the sensor for making filament as it can be opened and prevent jams when extruded filament is too thick. Connections should be straightforward and are outlined in the code. No smd soldering tools are required. The sensor is read 4 times per second. The code doesn't smooth readings, therefore it is very sensible. By looking at the shape of the trail is shaggy you can tell if the filament is regular, has bubbles or even little imperfections. I have samples of my own filament to give away for the cost of shipment, contact me via private message if you're interested. Update 22/2/2015: I updated the arduino code and uploaded a processing sketch useful for debugging

Another one for my sewing girl friend:  
This weights are used for fixing fabrics while cutting it on a cutting mat. Many people use large heavy metal washers for this job.  
Depending on the source where you buy those washers and the metal quality these washers are a little greasy or tend to rust. In addition they do not have a handle to move them around.   
Some people wrap those washers in fabric and add a button. I want to provide an alternative that takes much less work.  
I made this little ABS-pieces to wrap the washers and make them easy to handle. In addition i designed them stackable. Each weight can hold 1 or 2 washers. Stack them to double weight or while not in use.  
These things are designed for washers with 70 mm outer diameter and a hole of about 20 mm. Use the uploaded FreeCAD file to modify the outer diameter as you need. Inner diameter cannot be modified easy as this could break stackability.  
Print them with a thick perimeter (at least 1 mm) to give them a little strength. 3 top- and bottom layers of 0,2 mm are sufficient. I only tried ABS but there is no reason why PLA should not work too. Nylon would be a nice try too.  
How to customize:  
Just open the FreeCAD file (I use FreeCAD 0.14 and 0.15). Locate the revolution object in the model tree and set its visibility to "false" to be able to see the sketch. Then double click on the sketch located "inside" the revolution. Find the horizontal line constraint to 26,5 mm and change to whatever you need. Close and set the revolution object to "visible" again. Save as stl file, slice, print and enjoy.

Due to the camera I recently attached to the front door of my MakerBot (Details of which can be found on my profile), the added mass prevents the door from remaining open. To overcome this I decided to design a latch which would automatically hold the door open, when needed. It mounts to the 2X using the existing external bolt holes, however requires longer bolts. A 3mm metal rod is also used as the axis. To make it automatic, a spring is also added. At rest the latch is in the closed position. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v0MLV1cKca0

title: Hubsan X4 full prop guard (7mm and 8.5mm versions)

description.text:
A full prop guard for the Hubsan X4 quadcopter. Pretty sturdy, but probably still breaks when you crash really hard due to the nature of 3D printed things being relatively weak when it comes to layer adhesion.  
The version with 8,66 mm holes will fit when printed on a Zortrax M200 with 0,14 mm layer heigt.   
Weight is probably a tad more than the original guard.

You will need to use supports to print this thing. On a Zortrax, support lite works fine. I have printed these on my Zortrax M200 with great results using these settings:
  • Material: Z-ABS
  • Layer height: 0,14 mm
  • Support: support lite

The eBay listing is not mine,

Like many who post things to this site, creating this file was an investment of my time and energy.
My only intention to create enjoyment and to inspire others in the maker community.

comments.author: jmabry

comments.text: Well, for what it is worth, you can instruct them to take down the listing.  As per the User agreement here on thingiverse, we all agree to honor the intellectual property rights of the creators.  Whenever we post things here, we have a level of copyright protection that makerbot will protect; however, thingiverse requires us to spell out our permissions in the item description. For example: "This item may be reproduced for personal use but it may not be reproduced for resell."
comments.author: jmabry

comments.text: I want to thank you Mysabre73 for bringing this to my attention. I have contacted this seller to pull this eBay listing twice under CCL. The first time they argued that they were simply providing a 'service' printing my file. The second time they simply replied 'Sure'. The seller continues to offer prints of my file on eBay, and at last count has made nearly $500 from this venture. I now see another eBay lister selling the updated version I posted. It seems that cordial contact has failed and may force me to take legal action. The most damaging part will be to the Thingiverse community. I have been working on a third version and other TIE that fixes allot of the weight and carry issues and I have other variants of the TIE ready to post (Advanced, Interceptor, and Bomber). Fred is a character on Fitocracy's site that I created quickly to try out the MakerBot 3d printer that was being shown at a nearby workshop. The example photo shows the printed piece in the lowest resolution.

The Fitocracy Fred mascot was created using a free 3d program called Blender. I've been using for several years and I discovered it actually allows output to a .stl file. The model is pretty simple. I started with a photo of the front and side. Then I just modelled it, using the photo as guides. It's made up of geometric shapes and maybe the most difficult thing to make was the barbell on the model's chest. Aside from that, it's cubes with rounded corners. INSTRUCTIONS ON HOW TO PRINT OUT

  • When the pieces get imported into the MakerBot app, be sure to change the scale. I set mine to 600%.

  • Turn the body and face (or head) upside down. It'll print better that way.

  • The ears were a bit of a pain as they're so tiny. I used an Xacto knife to cut away the excess plastic. For the ears, I've made a tiny mark located on the head. That part needs to be cut out so the ear part can be added.

  • Assemble and stick with a glue gun or glue.

author: turfgnome

description.text:
Cabbage white butterflies are antisocial when they're laying their eggs. So if you stick up decoy butterflies, you can scare them off your crops. It's slightly oversize so it looks more intimidating to butterflies. Feel free to evolve the design.
Ignore butterflies attempting to mate with your decoy. They are stupid males and will not be laying eggs.

Print in white (or spray) and melt/glue a piece of filament into the socket on the underside of the butterfly. Warm up a strip down the middle of the "body" and bend the wings up a bit into what aeronautical types call a dihedral.
Draw a black spot in the middle of each of the two smaller wing lobes with permanent marker, and plant so that it is visible above your crops. Relax in a caterpillar-free environment.

comments.text: I printed a dozen of these for around the garden and after a week they seem to be working a treat! Our brassicas are caterpillar-free so far.

title: ACRYLIC LED ORGAN lasercutting WS2812 DIGI-DOT-RING based, LED-player with JINX! LED matrix software or stand alone

description.text:
ACRYLIC LED ORGAN lasercutting WS2812 DIGI-DOT-RING based, LED-player with JINX! LED matrix software or stand alone Deutsche Übersetzung unten ! A small light effect lamp made from laser-cut plexiglass.
The file includes all necessary parts.
The thickness of the plexiglass needs to be taken into account.
Assembling it is relatively easy.
The small but strong neodymium magnets in the plexiglass used for the bottom and as a lid are closing the lamp safely.
The main ring has a 24 LED DIGI-DOT-RING embedded within it (http://www.led-genial.de/DIGI-DOT-Ring-mit-24-x-WS2812B-LEDs).
Each one of the WS2812 LEDs contains an integrated PWM chip so they can be selected individually, every one of them having 16 million colors and 256 levels of brightness.
In order to achieve this one also needs a WS2812 controller.
An Arduino could be used very well but it is way too large.
The more elegant solution is the LED-Player (http://www.led-genial.de/LED-Player-spielt-LED-Effekte-von-SD-Karte-ab) or the LED-Stamp (http://www.led-genial.de/LED-Stamp-die-LED-Briefmarke-fuer-WS2812) by Diamex.
These controllers can be embedded directly and they have to be soldered onto the pixel ring.
There are just three small spots where they have to be attached.
Afterwards just attach the lamp to a PC via a USB cable, a cellphone power supply or a power bank.
While the LED-Stamp already has a few finished programs in store, the SD-LED-Player offers a lot more.
The player can be controlled via a USB port and the software Jinx! (http://www.live-leds.de) in order to create great effects.
One can also create audio and camera effects easily.
They can even be saved as a file. These can be transferred to an SD card so the player will play the files even without the use of a PC.
Several of these files can be saved on an SD card, their number varying with the latter’s individual capacity, and this way the files can be played after one another.
So there is a lot of room to experiment.
Have fun assembling it! Don't forget to visit our site http://www.led-genial.de for further information on our technology, research and creations. Eine kleine Effektlampe aus lasergeschnittenen Plexiglas. In der Datei sind alle Teile abgelegt. Die Dicke der Scheiben sollte beachtet werden. Der Zusammenbau ist recht einfach. Die kleinen aber starken Neodym-Magnete in der Grundplatte und Deckel verschließen die Konstruktion sicher. In dem Hauptring ist ein 24 DIGI-DOT-RING (http://www.led-genial.de/DIGI-DOT-Ring-mit-24-x-WS2812B-LEDs ) eingebettet. Die WS2812 LEDs haben je einen eingebauten PWM-Chip, können also einzeln und individuell angesteuert werden. Jede einzelne mit 16 Millionen Farben und 256 Helligkeitsstufen. Um das zu schaffen benötigt man noch einen WS2812-Controller. Dazu eignet sich ein Arduino recht gut, der ist nur viel zu groß. Viel eleganter geht es mit dem LED-Player (http://www.led-genial.de/LED-Player-spielt-LED-Effekte-von-SD-Karte-ab) oder der LED-Stamp (http://www.led-genial.de/LED-Stamp-die-LED-Briefmarke-fuer-WS2812 ) von Diamex. Diese Controller kann man direkt einbauen und direkt auf den Pixelring auflöten. Es sind nur drei kleine Lötstellen. Danach einfach mit einer USB-Leitung an den PC, Handynetzteil oder Powerbank anschließen, schon geht es los. Während die LED-Stamp schon ein paar fertige Programme mitbringt, kann der SD-LED-Player sehr viel mehr. Über den USB-Port lässt sich der Player via der Software Jinx! (http://www.live-leds.de) fabelhaft ansteuern, tolle Effekte kann man hier kreieren. Auch Audio und Kameraeffekte sind kinderleicht zu erstellen. Die sind sogar als Datei abspeicherbar und man kann diese auf SD-Card ablegen und mit dem Player ganz ohne PC abspielen. Mehrere dieser Dateien sind auf der SD-Card abspeicherbar, je nach Kapazität und hintereinander abspielbar. Man hat also viel Spielraum zu experimentieren. Viel Spaß beim Nachbau. Noch mehr interessante WS2812-Controller auf unserer Website http://www.led-genial.de --- bitte besuchen!

REMIX found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:84108 Since I liked the banana tuning from Jeremy: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:45236
but some people might not want to change their blocks. So I designed a working version that one can bolt on existing UM blocks. I prefer to use solid blocks from chasmaker: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22157. It allows me to bolt on the tensioner with small bolts. Use 10mm M3 bolts for mounting to chasmakers blocks. If you use longer ones for the tensioner check if endswitches work. Leave everything else original on the blocks. So if you have wooden blocks with long bolts already through them. Just remove the nuts. Screw back the bolts a bit and then use the tensioner as replacement of your nuts. So the tensioning bolts on the lever stay unchanged. It's often just a hair of adjustment extra needed. Cura settings: .4mm nozzle and wall thickness, 100% infill.
Rotate the tens-case stl file 180 else you have to bridge. Solidworks messed up. Troubles rotanting the assembly. Solidworks parts and assembly added. Do with it as you please. Please do improve.
PS it was a very tight squeeze. I hope it fits for all. But it fits on my stock UM.

comments.text: Well chasmaker offers 2 versions, the solid one, or like the wood layers style, the wood style is 1 on 1 copy from i think a laser drawing, considering the bolt holes are 2.8 mm and not 3. Version 2 is a dimensionally correct copy with merged wood layers. Either way the end result is a copy of original dimensions. Since I imported the solid chasmaker block, sketched on the surface, converted entities, and extruded the sketch, so thats the reason in size change of the 4 bolt holes. And yes they use 30mm bolts, only the solid version of the blocks do not required to be holded together. So it saves you 4 30mm bolts. leaving empty bolt holes. Untabbed. Thats the reason i didn't change the 2.8 mm. So it will grib the thread of your bolt on a stock wooden linear block and replaces the 4 nuts. author: shocker

description.text: Remixed to be easily printable in halves without supports. Plus some smoothing to get rid of the sharp edges. Keep your hens happy - print one for them today!

This is the only thing I have found that I can make that will actually sell.
It can't be patented, the idea was covered by a patent that expired a long time ago. I have made well over a hundred of these, they used to cost 25p each to make and sell very well on Ebay for £1. They don't tend to sell well above £1.
THIS IS NOT TO PROTECT CHILDREN.
THIS IS TO PROTECT EQUIPMENT FROM CHILDREN.
The design looks strange, but that is because I searched for information on every mains socket I could find then used the data gained to make this design that should fit every available Mains Socket.
This is version 4, previous versions were simpler in design, but could get returned due to not fitting. This design has never been returned.

I have printed in various colours in ABS and PLA, it prints well in either. I usually print at 0.3mm layer but any layer size should work. It's a thin plate, so infill doesn't matter.
After printing you need to remove the support from under the switch. This was not my idea, it was a request from my daughter. Around age of 6 months to a year and a half when young children become mobile, they tend to discover mains switches that make a really nice clicky sound. With UK mains sockets this is not really a safety issue to the child, but it can be a safety issue for equipment plugged into that socket. Switching off Sky boxes in mid record is annoying, multiple switching of PC causes it to fail expensively.
This simple plate stops children from accessing the switch.

title: Solid Rocket Motor Cutaway and Grain

description.text:
Rocket Propulsion is related to nozzle shape and the solid fuel inside its motor. This project consists of a cutaway view of a solid rocket motor and its main components - the motor case, insulation, ignitor, and the solid rocket fuel, called "grain," that fits inside.  The pattern of the grain influences the behavior of the rocket as the fuel is burned.  I have modeled seven types of grain in this project.
These cross sections of motors and fuel allow for exploration of the physics concepts related to thrust and momentum as well as geometric concepts like surface area, volume, and scale.  These models offer a  good starting point for any #ScienceProject or #EngineeringProject that relates to rocketry.  Teachers can also use this project to add a real-life application of #Math and #MathProjects through an exploration of surface area and reading graphs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard

Infill:

10%

Notes: I've included both the plain STLs and #MeshMixer STLs for the cutaway views. In printing, I found that standing the cutaways on end and printing without Mesh Mixer actually turned out better. The Mesh Mixer versions were a little hard to scrape off for no apparent benefit in stability or how the print turned out. The Motor Case and Insulation take about 3 hours to print together. Each cutaway of grain takes about 1:45 to print, and then the cross sections will take half and hour each. The little igniter plug takes less than 15 minutes.

To show off the cut away view of a solid rocket motor, you'll need to print the motor case, insulation, ignitor, and any or all of the grain that you wish to display.  The ignitor goes into the end that has the flared opening.  The other end is where the insulation goes.  On a real rocket, a nozzle of some sort would be attached at the insulation end to offer the surface for the expanding gasses to push against.

These models were all designed using #OnShape and are constrained to be printed on the #MakerbotMini. The cut away pieces will all fit together and would look smashing if you print them in different colors to make them stand out when assembled. The cross sections were taken directly from the models of the cutaway grains, so they are the size of the cutaways. If you want to have them larger to make things easier for smaller hands and larger measuring tools, you can resize them in MakerBot Desktop. To scale them up and be able to keep the thickness of the cross section under control, do your size modifications before you rotate the disk to lay flat. Scale up by whatever percentage or size you wish, then "uncheck" the box that keeps all changes proportional. Then, change the thickness back to 3 mm to whatever size you wish. I created a public file of this project in #OnShape. If you would like to model different patterns or sizes, feel free to access the project here.
NGSS

Cutaway and Cross Sectional Models of Solid Rocket Motors The race to space has become a commercial venture, with entrepreneurs, billionaires, and college students developing space craft and satellites. Our students will see a manned mission to Mars in their lifetimes. To understand how we get spacecraft off the ground (or missiles), this project provides an introduction to the design of solid rocket motors and how the design of the fuel inside influences the behavior of those rockets. Objectives Upon completion of this lesson, students will demonstrate an understanding of the impact of geometry, specifically surface area, on the behavior of rockets. They will gain an understanding of thrust and be able to demonstrate skills in reading thrust vs. time graphs. Standards Breakdown K-2-ETS1-1.
Ask questions, make observations, and gather information about a situation people want to change to define a simple problem that can be solved through the development of a new or improved object or tool.
K-2-ETS1-2.
Develop a simple sketch, drawing, or physical model to illustrate how the shape of an object helps it function as needed to solve a given problem. *MS-PS3-1 Energy
Construct and interpret graphical displays of data to describe the relationships of kinetic energy to the mass of an object and to the speed of an object. *MS-PS3-5 Energy
Construct, use, and present arguments to support the claim that when the kinetic energy of an object changes, energy is transferred to or from the object. *HS-PS3-1 Energy
Create a computational model to calculate the change in the energy of one component in a system when the change in energy of the other component(s) and energy flows in and out of the system are known. *HS-PS3-2 Energy
Develop and use models to illustrate that energy at the macroscopic scale can be accounted for as a combination of energy associated with the motions of particles (objects) and energy associated with the relative positions of particles (objects). *HS-PS1-4 Matter and its Interactions
Develop a model to illustrate that the release or absorption of energy from a chemical reaction system depends upon the changes in total bond energy.

Introducing the topic, examining the models, and performing an activity related to graphing, surface area, or hypothesizing about the appropriate grain configuration for a specified use could take a total of five one-hour sessions, or just two, depending on the depth of your studies. To prepare for the lesson, print the models ahead of time. The Motor Case, Insulation, Ignitor, and Grain fit together to show the interior of a typical solid rocket motor. These are for examination and example, but you don’t need to print one for every group. Then, print the cross sections of the various types of grain configurations for your students to work with - these will need to be printed in sufficient number for your students to work individually or in small groups.. The printing times and settings for each are as follows: To introduce rockets and the difference between liquid rockets and solid rocket motors, NASA is a great resource with a pictorial history of rockets as well as the behavior of model rockets. For a succinct explanation of the functions of both, the Bedford Astronomy Club put together this page, from which I created the design for the cutaway model of a solid rocket motor. UK Space has a nice page to show some of the various designs and sizes for rocket motors that were designed in the 1950’s and 60’s. Thrust behavior in a solid rocket motor is directly dependent on the configuration of the grain inside the motor. The surface of the grain combusts, exposing more grain, which combusts, and the process continues. NASA has this GIF that illustrates this nicely. This webpage has the thrust graphs for each grain configuration that is available in this project. Richard Nakka has documented numerous designs of motors and nozzles if you or your students wish to model and print more varieties. His website features data from countless tests and a thorough background on rockets, propulsion, and propellants. He has a lot of good links for further information as well. After introducing rockets and discussing solid rocket motors, you are ready to move on to evaluating the variety of grain configurations: students (or groups) should be given one grain cross section to work with. In Math and Science, you can ask your students to:
Use a true size determined by you to calculate scale, or work backwards, knowing the scale but not the true size.
Since surface area affects thrust behavior, calculate the surface area of this particular grain configuration, given a length specified by you.
Determine the cross sectional area of their piece of grain.
Determine the mass of the grain in a rocket if it was a length and scale that you give to the group. To determine the mass from the volume, students would need a density, which could be given as 1.70 g/mL.
Using the graphs of thrust v. time for various cross sections, students can create an initial thrust vs. surface area graph as a class. (If you choose this activity, make sure you are using the six cross-sections that align with the thrust v. time graphs). A follow on activity for this would be to hypothesize on what the graphs would look like for those cross sections that we don’t have graphs for. To incorporate more research and writing, this project can be expanded to ask students to hypothesize on the utility of a specific grain pattern and thrust v. time graph. In other words, “In what situation would you prefer to have the grain configuration that you have been assigned?” This activity will encourage students to investigate the various applications of rocket motors and to evaluate what rocket behavior would be preferred in those applications. For example, a booster rocket to launch a satellite would behave very differently from a surface to air missile or a bunker buster.

• K-2-ETS1-1
  • K-2-ETS1-2
  • MS-PS3-1 Energy
  • MS-PS3-5 Energy
  • HS-PS3-1 Energy
  • HS-PS3-2 Energy
  • HS-PS1-4 Matter

Students can be assessed on using measuring tools with accuracy and precision. They can also be assessed on mathematical computations, graphing skills, and communicating their results. If you pursue a research assignment, assessment can be based on ELA standards as well.

Lego axles in the most popular sizes available, including:  
2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, and 12.  
These are all measured from real Lego axles and printed to check if they work correctly.  They do.  
The ones printed in ABS seem to be the best choice strength-wise.  I sheared a few original axles making torque devices out of gears and axles, and the ABS is best.  However, Taulman's 618 nylon filament also works wonders for these.

Print at 100% infil, 0 shells for best results. Three ways to print: -Print on end, with rafting.
-Print on side, with support and rafting.
-Print on side, rotated 45 degrees, no support, no rafting. (Best option) Other tips: -Print slowly.
-Print at a lower temperature than you usually print.
-If able, pause briefly between layers.
